title: 107_hr4083
content: The "Corporate Responsibility Act of 2002" may require disgorgement. The Securities and Exchange Commission will prescribe regulations for disgorgement of earnings obtained through misconduct by officers or directors of an issuer. This applies if false or misleading financial statements were filed. The Securities and Exchange Commission may require disgorgement of benefits received from any source in connection with misconduct related to false or misleading financial statements or other violations of securities laws. The Securities and Exchange Commission may require disgorgement of benefits received from any source in connection with misconduct, including salary, commissions, fees, bonuses, options, profits, and losses avoided through securities transactions. SEC. 3. CEO AND CFO ACCOUNTABILITY FOR DISCLOSURE. The Securities and Exchange Commission requires company executives to certify the accuracy of financial reports filed under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. They must confirm the report's review, truthfulness, fair presentation of financial information, and accountability for its contents. The signing officers are responsible for establishing and maintaining internal controls to ensure material information is known to them, evaluating the effectiveness of internal controls within 90 days prior to the report, and disclosing significant deficiencies to auditors and the audit committee. The signing officers must report any significant deficiencies in internal controls that could impact financial reporting, disclose any fraud involving key employees, and indicate any changes in internal controls since their last evaluation. The rules must be effective within 30 days of the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REMOVAL OF UNFIT CORPORATE OFFICERS. The text discusses the removal of unfit corporate officers in both judicial and administrative proceedings under the Securities Act of 1933 and the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Amendments are made to replace "substantial unfitness" with "unfitness" in relevant sections. Additionally, the Securities Act of 1933 is amended to grant the Commission the authority to prohibit individuals who have violated specific sections from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers. Amendments to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 grant the Commission the authority to prohibit individuals who have violated specific sections from serving as officers or directors of registered issuers.
